statements.name: PROC OPTGRAPH
statements.description: The OPTGRAPH procedure can be used to analyze relationships between entities. These relationships are typically defined by using a graph.

arguments.name: DATA_LINKS=
arguments.description: specifies the input data set that contains the graph link information, where the links are defined as a list.

arguments.name: DATA_MATRIX=
arguments.description: specifies the input data set that contains the matrix to be processed. This is a generic matrix (as opposed to an adjacency matrix, which defines an underlying graph).

arguments.name: DATA_NODES=
arguments.description: specifies the input data set that contains the graph node information.

arguments.name: DATA_NODES_SUB=
arguments.description: specifies the input data set that contains the graph node subset information.

arguments.name: FILTER_SUBGRAPH=
arguments.description: specifies the minimum number of nodes allowed in a subgraph when processing is decomposed by cluster. The default setting is 0, so nothing is filtered by default.

arguments.name: GRAPH_DIRECTION=
arguments.description: specifies whether the input graph should be considered directed or undirected. By default, GRAPH_DIRECTION=UNDIRECTED.

arguments.name: DIRECTED
arguments.description: specifies the graph as directed.

arguments.name: UNDIRECTED
arguments.description: specifies the graph as undirected.

arguments.name: GRAPH_INTERNAL_FORMAT=
arguments.description: requests the internal graph format for the algorithms to use. By default, GRAPH_INTERNAL_FORMAT=FULL.

arguments.name: THIN
arguments.description: stores the graph in thin format.

arguments.name: FULL
arguments.description: stores the graph in standard (full) format.

arguments.name: INCLUDE_SELFLINK
arguments.description: includes self links when an input graph is read. By default, when PROC OPTGRAPH reads the DATA_LINKS= data set, it removes all self links.

arguments.name: LOGLEVEL=
arguments.description: controls the amount of information that is displayed in the SAS log. By default, LOGLEVEL=BASIC.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: turns off all procedure-related messages in the SAS log

arguments.name: BASIC
arguments.description: displays a basic summary of the input, output, and algorithmic processing

arguments.name: MODERATE
arguments.description: displays a summary of the input, output, and algorithmic processing

arguments.name: AGGRESSIVE
arguments.description: displays a detailed summary of the input, output, and algorithmic processing

arguments.name: OUT_LINKS=
arguments.description: specifies the output data set to contain the graph link information along with any results from the various algorithms that calculate metrics on links.

arguments.name: OUT_NODES=
arguments.description: specifies the output data set to contain the graph node information along with any results from the various algorithms that calculate metrics on nodes.

arguments.name: STANDARDIZED_LABELS
arguments.description: specifies that the input graph data is in a standardized format described in section Standardized Labels.

arguments.name: TIMETYPE=
arguments.description: specifies whether CPU time or real time is used for the MAXTIME= option for each applicable algorithm. By default, TIMETYPE=CPU.

arguments.name: CPU
arguments.description: specifies units of CPU time

arguments.name: REAL
arguments.description: specifies units of real time

statements.name: BICONCOMP
statements.description: The BICONCOMP statement requests that PROC OPTGRAPH find biconnected components and articulation points of an undirected input graph.

arguments.name: LOGLEVEL=
arguments.description: controls the amount of information that is displayed in the SAS log. The default is the value that is specified in the LOGLEVEL= option in the PROC OPTGRAPH statement (or BASIC if that option is not specified).

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: turns off all algorithm-related messages in the SAS log

arguments.name: BASIC
arguments.description: displays a basic summary of the algorithmic processing

arguments.name: MODERATE
arguments.description: displays a summary of the algorithmic processing

arguments.name: AGGRESSIVE
arguments.description: displays a detailed summary of the algorithmic processing

statements.name: CENTRALITY
statements.description: The CENTRALITY statement enables you to select which centrality metrics to calculate for the given input graph. It also enables you to specify options for particular metrics.

arguments.name: AUTH=
arguments.description: specifies which type of authority centrality to calculate.

arguments.name: WEIGHT
arguments.description: calculates authority centrality based on the weighted graph.

arguments.name: UNWEIGHT
arguments.description: calculates authority centrality based on the unweighted graph.

arguments.name: BOTH
arguments.description: calculates authority centrality based on both weighted and unweighted graphs.

arguments.name: BETWEEN=
arguments.description: specifies which type of betweenness centrality to calculate.

arguments.name: WEIGHT
arguments.description: calculates betweenness centrality based on the weighted graph.

arguments.name: UNWEIGHT
arguments.description: calculates betweenness centrality based on the unweighted graph.

arguments.name: BOTH
arguments.description: calculates betweenness centrality based on both weighted and unweighted graphs.

arguments.name: BETWEEN_NORM=
arguments.description: specifies whether to normalize the betweenness centrality metrics. By default, BETWEEN_NORM=YES.

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: normalizes the betweenness metrics.

arguments.name: NO
arguments.description: does not normalize the betweenness metrics.

arguments.name: BY_CLUSTER
arguments.description: decomposes the calculations by cluster (or subgraph).

arguments.name: CLOSE=
arguments.description: specifies which type of closeness centrality to calculate.

arguments.name: WEIGHT
arguments.description: calculates closeness centrality based on the weighted graph.

arguments.name: UNWEIGHT
arguments.description: calculates closeness centrality based on the unweighted graph.

arguments.name: BOTH
arguments.description: calculates closeness centrality based on both weighted and unweighted graphs.

arguments.name: CLOSE_NOPATH=
arguments.description: specifies a method for accounting for a shortest path between two nodes when a path does not exist (disconnected nodes). By default, CLOSE_NOPATH=DIAMETER.

arguments.name: NNODES
arguments.description: uses the number of nodes as a shortest path between disconnected nodes.

arguments.name: DIAMETER
arguments.description: uses the graph diameter (plus one) as a shortest path between disconnected nodes.

arguments.name: ZERO
arguments.description: uses zero as a shortest path between disconnected nodes.

arguments.name: HARMONIC
arguments.description: uses the harmonic formula for calculating closeness centrality.

arguments.name: CLUSTERING_COEF
arguments.description: calculates the node clustering coefficient.

arguments.name: DEGREE=
arguments.description: specifies which type of degree centrality to calculate for the input graph.

arguments.name: IN
arguments.description: calculates degree based on in-links.

arguments.name: OUT
arguments.description: calculates degree based on out-links.

arguments.name: BOTH
arguments.description: calculates degree based on in-links and out-links.

arguments.name: EIGEN=
arguments.description: specifies which type of eigenvector centrality to calculate.

arguments.name: WEIGHT
arguments.description: calculates eigenvector centrality based on the weighted graph.

arguments.name: UNWEIGHT
arguments.description: calculates centrality based on the unweighted graph.

arguments.name: BOTH
arguments.description: calculates centrality based on both weighted and unweighted graphs.

arguments.name: EIGEN_ALGORITHM=
arguments.description: specifies the algorithm to use in calculating centrality metrics that require solving eigensystems (EIGEN, HUB, and AUTH). By default, EIGEN_ALGORITHM=AUTOMATIC.

arguments.name: AUTOMATIC
arguments.description: requests that PROC OPTGRAPH automatically determine the eigensolver to use.

arguments.name: JACOBI_DAVIDSON
arguments.description: uses a variant of the Jacobi-Davidson algorithm for solving eigensystems (Sleijpen and van der Vorst 2000).

arguments.name: POWER
arguments.description: uses the power method to calculate eigenvectors.

arguments.name: EIGEN_MAXITER=
arguments.description: specifies the maximum number of iterations to use for eigenvector calculations to limit the amount of computation time spent when convergence is slow. By default, EIGEN_MAXITER=10,000.

arguments.name: HUB=
arguments.description: specifies which type of hub centrality to calculate.

arguments.name: WEIGHT
arguments.description: calculates hub centrality based on the weighted graph.

arguments.name: UNWEIGHT
arguments.description: calculates hub centrality based on the unweighted graph.

arguments.name: BOTH
arguments.description: calculates hub centrality based on both weighted and unweighted graphs.

arguments.name: INFLUENCE=
arguments.description: specifies which type of influence centrality to calculate.

arguments.name: WEIGHT
arguments.description: calculates influence centrality based on the weighted graph.

arguments.name: UNWEIGHT
arguments.description: calculates influence centrality based on the unweighted graph.

arguments.name: BOTH
arguments.description: calculates influence centrality based on both weighted and unweighted graphs.

arguments.name: LOGFREQNODE=
arguments.description: controls the frequency for displaying iteration logs for some of the centrality metrics. The value of number can be any integer greater than or equal to 1; the default is determined automatically based on the size of the graph.

arguments.name: LOGFREQTIME=
arguments.description: controls the frequency for displaying iteration logs for some of the centrality metrics. The value of number can be any integer greater than or equal to 1; the default is 5.

arguments.name: LOGLEVEL=
arguments.description: controls the amount of information that is displayed in the SAS log. The default is the value that is specified in the LOGLEVEL= option in the PROC OPTGRAPH statement (or BASIC if that option is not specified).

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: turns off all algorithm-related messages in the SAS log.

arguments.name: BASIC
arguments.description: displays a basic summary of the algorithmic processing.

arguments.name: MODERATE
arguments.description: displays a summary of the algorithmic processing including a progress log using the interval that is specified in the LOGFREQNODE= or LOGFREQTIME= option.

arguments.name: AGGRESSIVE
arguments.description: displays a detailed summary of the algorithmic processing including a progress log using the interval that is specified in the LOGFREQNODE= or LOGFREQTIME= option.

arguments.name: SUBSIZESWITCH=
arguments.description: specifies the size of the subgraphs (number of nodes) to run separately when you also specify the BY_CLUSTER option in this statement and a value greater than 1 for the NTHREADS= option in the PERFORMANCE statement. The default is 10,000.

arguments.name: WEIGHT2=
arguments.description: specifies the data set variable name for a second link weight.

statements.name: CLIQUE
statements.description: The CLIQUE statement invokes an algorithm that finds maximal cliques on the input graph.

arguments.name: LOGLEVEL=
arguments.description: controls the amount of information that is displayed in the SAS log. The default is the value that is specified in the LOGLEVEL= option in the PROC OPTGRAPH statement (or BASIC if that option is not specified).

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: turns off all algorithm-related messages in the SAS log

arguments.name: BASIC
arguments.description: displays a basic summary of the algorithmic processing

arguments.name: MODERATE
arguments.description: displays a summary of the algorithmic processing

arguments.name: AGGRESSIVE
arguments.description: displays a detailed summary of the algorithmic processing

arguments.name: MAXCLIQUES=
arguments.description: specifies the maximum number of cliques to return during clique calculations. The default is the positive number that has the largest absolute value that can be represented in your operating environment.

arguments.name: MAXTIME=
arguments.description: specifies the maximum amount of time to spend calculating cliques. The value of number can be any positive number; the default value is the positive number that has the largest absolute value that can be represented in your operating environment.

arguments.name: OUT=
arguments.description: specifies the output data set to contain the maximal cliques.

statements.name: COMMUNITY
statements.description: The COMMUNITY statement invokes an algorithm that detects communities of the input graph.

arguments.name: ALGORITHM=
arguments.description: specifies whether to use the Louvain algorithm (LOUVAIN), the label propagation algorithm (LABEL_PROP), or the parallel label propagation algorithm (PARALLEL_LABEL_PROP). The Louvain algorithm is the default.

arguments.name: LINK_REMOVAL_RATIO=
arguments.description: defines the percentage of small-weight links to be removed around each node neighborhood. The valid range is between 0 and 100. The default value is 10.

arguments.name: LOGLEVEL=
arguments.description: controls the amount of information that is displayed in the SAS log. The default is the value that you specify in the LOGLEVEL= option in the PROC OPTGRAPH statement (or BASIC if that option is not specified).

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: turns off all algorithm-related messages in the SAS log

arguments.name: BASIC
arguments.description: displays a basic summary of the algorithmic processing

arguments.name: MODERATE
arguments.description: displays a summary of the algorithmic processing

arguments.name: AGGRESSIVE
arguments.description: displays a detailed summary of the algorithmic processing

arguments.name: MAXITER=
arguments.description: specifies the maximum number of iterations allowed in the algorithm. The default is 20 when ALGORITHM=LOUVAIN and 100 when ALGORITHM=LABEL_PROP or ALGORITHM=PARALLEL_LABEL_PROP.

arguments.name: OUT_COMM_LINKS=
arguments.description: specifies the output data set that describes the links between communities.

arguments.name: OUT_COMMUNITY=
arguments.description: specifies the output data set that contains the number of nodes in each community.

arguments.name: OUT_LEVEL=
arguments.description: specifies the output data set that contains community information at different resolution levels.

arguments.name: OUT_OVERLAP=
arguments.description: specifies the output data set that describes the intensity of each node.

arguments.name: RANDOM_FACTOR=
arguments.description: specifies the random factor for the parallel label propagation algorithm. Specify a number between 0 and 1. The default is 0.15, which means that 15% of nodes skip the label propagation step at each iteration.

arguments.name: RANDOM_SEED=
arguments.description: specifies the random seed for the parallel label propagation algorithm. By default, RANDOM_SEED=1234.

arguments.name: RECURSIVE
arguments.description: requests that the algorithm recursively break down large communities into smaller ones until the specified conditions are satisfied.

arguments.name: MAX_COMM_SIZE=
arguments.description: specifies the maximum number of nodes to be contained in any community.

arguments.name: MAX_DIAMETER=
arguments.description: specifies the maximum number of links on the shortest paths between any pair of nodes in any community.

arguments.name: RELATION=
arguments.description: Specifies the relationship between the values of MAX_COMM_SIZE= and MAX_DIAMETER= options.

arguments.name: RESOLUTION_LIST=
arguments.description: specifies a list of resolution values that are separated by spaces. The OPTGRAPH procedure interprets the RESOLUTION_LIST= option differently depending on the value of the ALGORITHM= option.

arguments.name: TOLERANCE=
arguments.description: specifies the tolerance value for when to stop iterations. The valid range is strictly between 0 and 1. By default, TOLERANCE=0.01.

statements.name: CONCOMP
statements.description: The CONCOMP statement invokes an algorithm that finds the connected components of the input graph.

arguments.name: ALGORITHM=
arguments.description: specifies the algorithm to use for calculating connected components. By default, ALGORITHM=UNION_FIND for undirected graphs, and ALGORITHM=DFS for directed graphs.

arguments.name: DFS
arguments.description: uses the depth-first search algorithm for connected components.

arguments.name: UNION_FIND
arguments.description: uses the union-find algorithm for connected components.

arguments.name: LOGLEVEL=
arguments.description: controls the amount of information that is displayed in the SAS log. The default is the value that is specified in the LOGLEVEL= option in the PROC OPTGRAPH statement (or BASIC if that option is not specified).

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: turns off all algorithm-related messages in the SAS log.

arguments.name: BASIC
arguments.description: displays a basic summary of the algorithmic processing

arguments.name: MODERATE
arguments.description: displays a summary of the algorithmic processing

arguments.name: AGGRESSIVE
arguments.description: displays a detailed summary of the algorithmic processing

statements.name: CORE
statements.description: The CORE statement invokes an algorithm that finds the core decomposition of the input graph.

arguments.name: LINKS=
arguments.description: specifies which type of cores to calculate for a directed graph. You can choose to calculate the cores based on in-links (IN), out-links (OUT), or both (BOTH). For an undirected graph, core applies only to out-links. By default, LINKS=OUT.

arguments.name: IN
arguments.description: calculates core based on in-links.

arguments.name: OUT
arguments.description: calculates core based on out-links.

arguments.name: BOTH
arguments.description: calculates core based on in-links and out-links.

arguments.name: LOGLEVEL=
arguments.description: controls the amount of information that is displayed in the SAS log. The default is the value that is specified in the LOGLEVEL= option in the PROC OPTGRAPH statement (or BASIC if that option is not specified).

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: turns off all algorithm-related messages in the SAS log

arguments.name: BASIC
arguments.description: displays a basic summary of the algorithmic processing

arguments.name: MODERATE
arguments.description: displays a summary of the algorithmic processing

arguments.name: AGGRESSIVE
arguments.description: displays a detailed summary of the algorithmic processing

arguments.name: MAXTIME=
arguments.description: specifies the maximum amount of time to spend in the core decomposition algorithm. The value of number can be any positive number; the default value is the positive number that has the largest absolute value that can be represented in your operating environment.

statements.name: CYCLE
statements.description: The CYCLE statement invokes an algorithm that finds the cycles (or the existence of a cycle) in the input graph.

arguments.name: LOGLEVEL=
arguments.description: controls the amount of information that is displayed in the SAS log. The default is the value that is specified in the LOGLEVEL= option in the PROC OPTGRAPH statement (or BASIC if that option is not specified).

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: turns off all algorithm-related messages in the SAS log

arguments.name: BASIC
arguments.description: displays a basic summary of the algorithmic processing

arguments.name: MODERATE
arguments.description: displays a summary of the algorithmic processing

arguments.name: AGGRESSIVE
arguments.description: displays a detailed summary of the algorithmic processing

arguments.name: MAXCYCLES=
arguments.description: specifies the maximum number of cycles to return. The default is the positive number that has the largest absolute value representable in your operating environment.

arguments.name: MAXLENGTH=
arguments.description: specifies the maximum number of links to allow in a cycle. The default is the positive number that has the largest absolute value that can be represented in your operating environment. By default, nothing is removed from the results.

arguments.name: MAXLINKWEIGHT=
arguments.description: specifies the maximum sum of link weights to allow in a cycle. The default is the positive number that has the largest absolute value that can be represented in your operating environment. By default, nothing is filtered.

arguments.name: MAXNODEWEIGHT=
arguments.description: specifies the maximum sum of node weights to allow in a cycle. The default is the positive number that has the largest absolute value that can be represented in your operating environment. By default, nothing is filtered.

arguments.name: MAXTIME=
arguments.description: specifies the maximum amount of time to spend finding cycles. The value of number can be any positive number; the default value is the positive number that has the largest absolute value that can be represented in your operating environment.

arguments.name: MINLENGTH=
arguments.description: specifies the minimum number of links to allow in a cycle. By default MINLENGTH=1 and nothing is filtered.

arguments.name: MINLINKWEIGHT=
arguments.description: specifies the minimum sum of link weights to allow in a cycle. The default is the negative number that has the largest absolute value that can be represented in your operating environment. By default, nothing is filtered.

arguments.name: MINNODEWEIGHT=
arguments.description: specifies the minimum sum of node weights to allow in a cycle. The default is the negative number that has the largest absolute value that can be represented in your operating environment. By default, nothing is filtered.

arguments.name: MODE=
arguments.description: specifies the mode for processing cycles. By default, MODE=FIRST_CYCLE.

arguments.name: ALL_CYCLES
arguments.description: returns all (unique, elementary) cycles found.

arguments.name: FIRST_CYCLE
arguments.description: returns the first cycle found.

arguments.name: OUT=
arguments.description: specifies the output data set to contain the cycles found.

statements.name: DATA_LINKS_VAR
statements.description: The DATA_LINKS_VAR statement enables you to explicitly define the data set variable names for PROC OPTGRAPH to use when it reads the data set that is specified in the DATA_LINKS= option in the PROC OPTGRAPH statement.

arguments.name: FROM=
arguments.description: specifies the data set variable name forfrom nodes.

arguments.name: LOWER=
arguments.description: specifies the data set variable name for link flow lower bounds.

arguments.name: TO=
arguments.description: specifies the data set variable name for to node.

arguments.name: UPPER=
arguments.description: specifies the data set variable name for link flow upper bounds.

arguments.name: WEIGHT=
arguments.description: specifies the data set variable name for link weights.

statements.name: DATA_MATRIX_VAR
statements.description: The DATA_MATRIX_VAR statement enables you to explicitly define the data set variable names for PROC OPTGRAPH to use when it reads the data set that is specified in the DATA_MATRIX= option in the PROC OPTGRAPH statement.

statements.name: DATA_NODES_VAR
statements.description: The DATA_NODES_VAR statement enables you to explicitly define the data set variable names for PROC OPTGRAPH to use when it reads the data set that is specified in the DATA_NODES= option in the PROC OPTGRAPH statement.

arguments.name: CLUSTER=
arguments.description: specifies the data set variable name for clusters identifiers.

arguments.name: NODE=
arguments.description: specifies the data set variable name for the nodes.

arguments.name: WEIGHT=
arguments.description: specifies the data set variable name for node weights.

arguments.name: WEIGHT2=
arguments.description: specifies the data set variable name for auxiliary node weights.

statements.name: EIGENVECTOR
statements.description: The EIGENVECTOR statement invokes a variant of the Jacobi-Davidson algorithm (Sleijpen and van der Vorst 2000) that finds eigenvectors (and eigenvalues) for symmetric matrices.

arguments.name: EIGENVALUES=
arguments.description: specifies the type of eigenvector to calculate. By default, EIGENVALUES=LA.

arguments.name: LA
arguments.description: calculates the n largest algebraic eigenvalues (and their corresponding eigenvectors), where n is the value of the NEIGEN= option.

arguments.name: SA
arguments.description: calculates the n smallest algebraic eigenvalues (and their corresponding eigenvectors), where n is the value of the NEIGEN= option.

arguments.name: LOGLEVEL=
arguments.description: controls the amount of information that is displayed in the SAS log. The default is the value that is specified in the LOGLEVEL= option in the PROC OPTGRAPH statement (or BASIC if that option is not specified).

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: turns off all algorithm-related messages in the SAS log

arguments.name: BASIC
arguments.description: displays a basic summary of the algorithmic processing

arguments.name: MODERATE
arguments.description: displays a summary of the algorithmic processing

arguments.name: AGGRESSIVE
arguments.description: displays a detailed summary of the algorithmic processing

arguments.name: MAXITER=
arguments.description: specifies the maximum number of matrix-vector multiplications used in the Jacobi-Davidson algorithm to calculate eigenvectors. By default, MAXITER=10,000.

arguments.name: NEIGEN=
arguments.description: specifies the number of eigenvalues (and their corresponding eigenvectors) to generate. This value must be less than or equal to the dimension of the matrix. By default, NEIGEN=1.

arguments.name: OUT=
arguments.description: specifies the output data set to contain the eigenvectors (and eigenvalues) found.

statements.name: LINEAR_ASSIGNMENT
statements.description: The LINEAR_ASSIGNMENT statement invokes an algorithm that solves the minimal-cost linear assignment problem. In graph terms, this problem is also known as the minimum link-weighted matching problem on a bipartite graph.

arguments.name: ID=
arguments.description: specifies the data set variable names that identify the matrix rows (from nodes).

arguments.name: LOGLEVEL=
arguments.description: controls the amount of information that is displayed in the SAS log. The default is the value that is specified in the LOGLEVEL= option in the PROC OPTGRAPH statement (or BASIC if that option is not specified).

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: turns off all algorithm-related messages in the SAS log

arguments.name: BASIC
arguments.description: displays a basic summary of the algorithmic processing

arguments.name: MODERATE
arguments.description: displays a summary of the algorithmic processing

arguments.name: AGGRESSIVE
arguments.description: displays a detailed summary of the algorithmic processing

arguments.name: OUT=
arguments.description: specifies the output data set to contain the solution to the linear assignment problem.

arguments.name: WEIGHT=
arguments.description: specifies the data set variable names for the cost matrix.

statements.name: MINCOSTFLOW
statements.description: The MINCOSTFLOW statement invokes an algorithm that solves the minimum-cost network flow problem on an input graph.

arguments.name: LOGFREQ=
arguments.description: controls the frequency for displaying iteration logs for minimum-cost network flow calculations that use the network simplex algorithm. For graphs that contain one component, this option displays progress every number simplex iterations, and the default is 10,000.

arguments.name: LOGLEVEL=
arguments.description: controls the amount of information that is displayed in the SAS log. The default is the value that is specified in the LOGLEVEL= option in the PROC OPTGRAPH statement (or BASIC if that option is not specified).

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: turns off all algorithm-related messages in the SAS log

arguments.name: BASIC
arguments.description: displays a basic summary of the algorithmic processing

arguments.name: MODERATE
arguments.description: displays a summary of the algorithmic processing including a progress log using the interval that is specified in the LOGFREQ= option

arguments.name: AGGRESSIVE
arguments.description: displays a detailed summary of the algorithmic processing including a progress log using the interval that is specified in the LOGFREQ= option

arguments.name: MAXTIME=
arguments.description: specifies the maximum amount of time to spend calculating minimum-cost network flows. The type of time (either CPU time or real time) is determined by the value of the TIMETYPE= option. The value of number can be any positive number; the default value is the positive number that has the largest absolute value that can be represented in your operating environment.

statements.name: MINCUT
statements.description: The MINCUT statement invokes an algorithm that finds the minimum link-weighted cut of an input graph.

arguments.name: LOGLEVEL=
arguments.description: controls the amount of information that is displayed in the SAS log. The default is the value that is specified in the LOGLEVEL= option in the PROC OPTGRAPH statement (or BASIC if that option is not specified).

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: turns off all algorithm-related messages in the SAS log

arguments.name: BASIC
arguments.description: displays a basic summary of the algorithmic processing

arguments.name: MODERATE
arguments.description: displays a summary of the algorithmic processing

arguments.name: AGGRESSIVE
arguments.description: displays a detailed summary of the algorithmic processing

arguments.name: MAXNUMCUTS=
arguments.description: specifies the maximum number of cuts to return from the algorithm. The minimal cut and any others found during the search, up to number, are returned. By default, MAXNUMCUTS=1.

arguments.name: MAXWEIGHT=
arguments.description: specifies the maximum weight of the cuts to return from the algorithm. The default is the positive number that has the largest absolute value that can be represented in your operating environment.

arguments.name: OUT=
arguments.description: specifies the output data set to contain the solution to the minimum-cut problem.

statements.name: MINSPANTREE
statements.description: The MINSPANTREE statement invokes an algorithm that solves the minimum link-weighted spanning tree problem on an input graph.

arguments.name: LOGLEVEL=
arguments.description: controls the amount of information that is displayed in the SAS log. The default is the value that is specified in the LOGLEVEL= option in the PROC OPTGRAPH statement (or BASIC if that option is not specified).

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: turns off all algorithm-related messages in the SAS log

arguments.name: BASIC
arguments.description: displays a basic summary of the algorithmic processing

arguments.name: MODERATE
arguments.description: displays a summary of the algorithmic processing

arguments.name: AGGRESSIVE
arguments.description: displays a detailed summary of the algorithmic processing

arguments.name: OUT=
arguments.description: specifies the output data set to contain the solution to the minimum link-weighted spanning tree problem.

statements.name: PERFORMANCE
statements.description: The PERFORMANCE statement specifies performance options for multithreaded computing and requests detailed results about the performance characteristics of the OPTGRAPH procedure. The PERFORMANCE statement enables you to control the number of threads used and the output of the ODS table that reports procedure timing.

arguments.name: DETAILS
arguments.description: requests that PROC OPTGRAPH produce the Timing ODS table, which shows a breakdown of the time used in each step of the procedure.

arguments.name: NTHREADS=
arguments.description: specifies the number of threads that PROC OPTGRAPH can use. The default value is CPUCOUNT, which sets the thread count to the number determined by the SAS system option CPUCOUNT=.

statements.name: REACH
statements.description: The REACH statement invokes an algorithm that calculates the reach (ego) network on an input graph.

arguments.name: BY_CLUSTER
arguments.description: decomposes the calculations by cluster (subgraph).

arguments.name: DIGRAPH
arguments.description: calculates the directed reach counts when computing the reach networks and includes the directed counts in the resulting output data set that is specified in the OUT_COUNTS= option.

arguments.name: EACH_SOURCE
arguments.description: treats each node as a source and calculates a reach network from each one.

arguments.name: IGNORE_SELF
arguments.description: ignores the source nodes in the reach network node counts.

arguments.name: LOGFREQTIME=
arguments.description: displays iteration logs for the reach algorithm every number seconds. The value of number can be any integer greater than or equal to 1; the default is 5.

arguments.name: LOGLEVEL=
arguments.description: controls the amount of information that is displayed in the SAS log. The default is the value that is specified in the LOGLEVEL= option in the PROC OPTGRAPH statement (or BASIC if that option is not specified).

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: turns off all algorithm-related messages in the SAS log

arguments.name: BASIC
arguments.description: displays a basic summary of the algorithmic processing

arguments.name: MODERATE
arguments.description: displays a summary of the algorithmic processing

arguments.name: AGGRESSIVE
arguments.description: displays a detailed summary of the algorithmic processing

arguments.name: MAXREACH=
arguments.description: specifies the maximum number of links to allow from each source node in a reach network. By default, MAXREACH=1.

arguments.name: OUT_COUNTS=
arguments.description: specifies the output data set to contain the node counts in each reach network.

arguments.name: OUT_COUNTS1=
arguments.description: specifies the output data set to contain the node counts in each reach network for the special case of calculating only counts that have limit 1 and 2. This data set holds the counts with MAXREACH=1.

arguments.name: OUT_COUNTS2=
arguments.description: specifies the output data set to contain the node counts in each reach network for the special case of calculating only counts that have limit 1 and 2. This data set holds the counts with MAXREACH=2.

arguments.name: OUT_LINKS=
arguments.description: specifies the output data set to contain the links in each reach network.

arguments.name: OUT_NODES=
arguments.description: specifies the output data set to contain the nodes in each reach network.

statements.name: SHORTPATH
statements.description: The SHORTPATH statement invokes an algorithm that calculates shortest paths between sets of nodes on the input graph.

arguments.name: LOGFREQ=
arguments.description: displays iteration logs for shortest path calculations every number nodes. The default is determined automatically based on the size of the graph.

arguments.name: LOGLEVEL=
arguments.description: controls the amount of information that is displayed in the SAS log. The default is the value that is specified in the LOGLEVEL= option in the PROC OPTGRAPH statement (or BASIC if that option is not specified).

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: turns off all algorithm-related messages in the SAS log

arguments.name: BASIC
arguments.description: displays a basic summary of the algorithmic processing

arguments.name: MODERATE
arguments.description: Displays a summary of the algorithmic processing

arguments.name: AGGRESSIVE
arguments.description: displays a detailed summary of the algorithmic processing

arguments.name: OUT_PATHS=
arguments.description: specifies the output data set to contain the shortest paths.

arguments.name: OUT_WEIGHTS=
arguments.description: specifies the output data set to contain the shortest path summaries.

arguments.name: PATHS=
arguments.description: specifies the type of output to produce in the output data set that is specified in the OUT_PATHS= option. By default, PATHS=ALL.

arguments.name: ALL
arguments.description: outputs shortest paths for all pairs of source-sinks.

arguments.name: LONGEST
arguments.description: outputs shortest paths for the source-sink pair with the longest (finite) length. If other source-sink pairs (up to 100) have equally long length, they are also output.

arguments.name: SHORTEST
arguments.description: outputs shortest paths for the source-sink pair with the shortest length. If other source-sink pairs (up to 100) have equally short length, they are also output.

arguments.name: SINK=
arguments.description: specifies the sink node for shortest paths calculations.

arguments.name: SOURCE=
arguments.description: specifies the source node for shortest paths calculations.

arguments.name: USEWEIGHT=
arguments.description: specifies whether to use link weights (if they exist) in calculating shortest paths. By default, USEWEIGHT=YES.

arguments.name: YES
arguments.description: uses weights (if they exist) in shortest path calculations.

arguments.name: NO
arguments.description: does not use weights in shortest path calculations.

arguments.name: WEIGHT2=
arguments.description: specifies the data set variable name for the auxiliary link weights.

statements.name: SUMMARY
statements.description: The SUMMARY statement invokes an algorithm that calculates various summary metrics on an input graph.

arguments.name: BICONCOMP
arguments.description: specifies whether to calculate information about biconnected components. The graph must be undirected.

arguments.name: BY_CLUSTER
arguments.description: specifies whether to decompose the calculations by cluster (or subgraph).

arguments.name: CONCOMP
arguments.description: specifies whether to calculate information about connected components.

arguments.name: DIAMETER_APPROX=
arguments.description: specifies whether to calculate information about the approximate diameter and what type of calculations to perform.

arguments.name: WEIGHT
arguments.description: calculates approximate diameter based on the weighted graph.

arguments.name: UNWEIGHT
arguments.description: calculates approximate diameter based on the unweighted graph.

arguments.name: BOTH
arguments.description: calculates approximate diameter based on both weighted and unweighted graphs.

arguments.name: LOGFREQNODE=
arguments.description: controls the frequency for displaying iteration logs for some of the summary metrics. The value of number can be any integer greater than or equal to 1. The default is determined automatically based on the size of the graph.

arguments.name: LOGFREQTIME=
arguments.description: controls the frequency for displaying iteration logs for some of the summary metrics. The value of number can be any integer greater than or equal to 1; the default is 5.

arguments.name: LOGLEVEL=
arguments.description: controls the amount of information that is displayed in the SAS log. The default is the value that is specified in the LOGLEVEL= option in the PROC OPTGRAPH statement (or BASIC if that option is not specified).

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: turns off all algorithm-related messages in the SAS log

arguments.name: BASIC
arguments.description: displays a basic summary of the algorithmic processing

arguments.name: MODERATE
arguments.description: displays a summary of the algorithmic processing

arguments.name: AGGRESSIVE
arguments.description: displays a detailed summary of the algorithmic processing

arguments.name: OUT=
arguments.description: specifies the output data set to contain the summary results.

arguments.name: SHORTPATH=
arguments.description: specifies whether to calculate information about shortest paths and what type of calculations to perform.

arguments.name: WEIGHT
arguments.description: calculates shortest paths based on the weighted graph.

arguments.name: UNWEIGHT
arguments.description: calculates shortest paths based on the unweighted graph.

arguments.name: BOTH
arguments.description: calculates shortest paths based on both weighted and unweighted graphs.

arguments.name: SUBSIZESWITCH=
arguments.description: specifies the size of the subgraphs (number of nodes) to run separately when you also specify the BY_CLUSTER option in this statement and a value greater than 1 for the NTHREADS= option in the PERFORMANCE statement. The default is 10,000.

statements.name: TRANSITIVE_CLOSURE
statements.description: The TRANSITIVE_CLOSURE statement invokes an algorithm that calculates the transitive closure of an input graph.

arguments.name: LOGLEVEL=
arguments.description: controls the amount of information that is displayed in the SAS log. The default is the value that is specified in the LOGLEVEL= option in the PROC OPTGRAPH statement (or BASIC if that option is not specified).

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: turns off all algorithm-related messages in the SAS log

arguments.name: BASIC
arguments.description: displays a basic summary of the algorithmic processing

arguments.name: MODERATE
arguments.description: displays a summary of the algorithmic processing

arguments.name: AGGRESSIVE
arguments.description: displays a detailed summary of the algorithmic processing

arguments.name: OUT=
arguments.description: specifies the output data set to contain the transitive closure results.

statements.name: TSP
statements.description: The TSP statement invokes an algorithm that solves the traveling salesman problem. The algorithm that is used to solve this problem is built around the same branch-and-cut method as is used in PROC OPTMILP.

arguments.name: ABSOBJGAP=
arguments.description: specifies a stopping criterion. When the absolute difference between the best integer objective and the objective of the best remaining branch-and-bound node becomes less than the value of number, the solver stops. The value of number can be any nonnegative number; the default value is 1E–6.

arguments.name: CONFLICTSEARCH=
arguments.description: specifies the level of conflict search that PROC OPTGRAPH performs. The solver performs a conflict search to find clauses that result from infeasible subproblems that arise in the search tree. By default, CONFLICTSEARCH=AUTOMATIC.

arguments.name: AUTOMATIC
arguments.description: performs a conflict search based on a strategy that is determined by PROC OPTGRAPH

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: disables conflict search

arguments.name: MODERATE
arguments.description: performs a moderate conflict search

arguments.name: AGGRESSIVE
arguments.description: performs an aggressive conflict search

arguments.name: CUTOFF=
arguments.description: cuts off any branch-and-bound nodes in a minimization problem that has an objective value that is greater than number. The value of number can be any number; the default value is the positive number that has the largest absolute value that can be represented in your operating environment.

arguments.name: CUTSTRATEGY=
arguments.description: specifies the level of mixed integer linear programming cutting planes to be generated by PROC OPTGRAPH. TSP-specific cutting planes are always generated. By default, CUTSTRATEGY=NONE.

arguments.name: AUTOMATIC
arguments.description: generates cutting planes based on a strategy determined by the mixed integer linear programming solver

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: disables generation of mixed integer linear programming cutting planes (some TSP-specific cutting planes are still active for validity)

arguments.name: MODERATE
arguments.description: uses a moderate cut strategy

arguments.name: AGGRESSIVE
arguments.description: uses an aggressive cut strategy

arguments.name: EMPHASIS=
arguments.description: specifies a search emphasis option. By default, EMPHASIS=BALANCE.

arguments.name: BALANCE
arguments.description: performs a balanced search

arguments.name: OPTIMAL
arguments.description: emphasizes optimality over feasibility

arguments.name: FEASIBLE
arguments.description: emphasizes feasibility over optimality

arguments.name: HEURISTICS=
arguments.description: controls the level of initial and primal heuristics that PROC OPTGRAPH applies. By default, HEURISTICS=AUTOMATIC.

arguments.name: AUTOMATIC
arguments.description: applies the default level of heuristics

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: disables all initial and primal heuristics

arguments.name: BASIC
arguments.description: applies basic intial and primal heuristics at low frequency

arguments.name: MODERATE
arguments.description: applies most intial and primal heuristics at moderate frequency

arguments.name: AGGRESSIVE
arguments.description: applies all intitial primal heuristics at high frequency

arguments.name: LOGFREQ=
arguments.description: specifies how often to print information in the branch-and-bound node log. The value of number can be any nonnegative integer up to the largest four-byte signed integer, which is 2³¹ - 1. The default value is 100.

arguments.name: LOGLEVEL=
arguments.description: controls the amount of information displayed in the SAS log by the solver, from a short description of presolve information and summary to details at each branch-and-bound node. The default value is MODERATE.

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: turns off all solver-related messages in the SAS log

arguments.name: BASIC
arguments.description: displays a solver summary after stopping

arguments.name: MODERATE
arguments.description: prints a solver summary and a node log by using the interval that is specified in the LOGFREQ= option

arguments.name: AGGRESSIVE
arguments.description: prints a detailed solver summary and a node log by using the interval that is specified in the LOGFREQ= option

arguments.name: MAXNODES=
arguments.description: specifies the maximum number of branch-and-bound nodes to be processed. The value of number can be any nonnegative integer up to the largest four-byte signed integer. The default value is 2³¹ - 1.

arguments.name: MAXSOLS=
arguments.description: specifies a stopping criterion. If number solutions have been found, then the procedure stops. The value of number can be any positive integer up to the largest four-byte signed integer. The default value is 2³¹ - 1.

arguments.name: MAXTIME=
arguments.description: specifies the maximum amount of time to spend solving the traveling salesman problem. The type of time (either CPU time or real time) is determined by the value of the TIMETYPE= option. The value of number can be any positive number; the default value is the positive number that has the largest absolute value that can be represented in your operating environment.

arguments.name: MILP=
arguments.description: specifies whether to use a mixed integer linear programming (MILP) solver for solving the traveling salesman problem. The MILP solver attempts to find the overall best TSP tour by using a branch-and-bound based algorithm. By default, MILP=ON.

arguments.name: ON
arguments.description: uses a mixed integer linear programming solver

arguments.name: OFF
arguments.description: does not use a mixed-integer linear programming solver

arguments.name: NODESEL=
arguments.description: specifies the branch-and-bound node selection strategy option. By default, NODESEL=AUTOMATIC.

arguments.name: AUTOMATIC
arguments.description: Uses automatic node selection

arguments.name: BESTBOUND
arguments.description: chooses the node with the best relaxed objective (best-bound-first strategy)

arguments.name: BESTESTIMATE
arguments.description: chooses the node with the best estimate of the integer objective value (best-estimate-first strategy)

arguments.name: DEPTH
arguments.description: chooses the most recently created node (depth-first strategy)

arguments.name: OUT=
arguments.description: specifies the output data set to contain the solution to the traveling salesman problem.

arguments.name: PROBE=
arguments.description: specifies a probing option. By default, PROBE=NONE.

arguments.name: AUTOMATIC
arguments.description: uses an automatic probing strategy

arguments.name: NONE
arguments.description: disables probing

arguments.name: MODERATE
arguments.description: uses the probing moderately

arguments.name: AGGRESSIVE
arguments.description: uses the probing aggressively

arguments.name: RELOBJGAP=
arguments.description: specifies a stopping criterion that is based on the best integer objective (BestInteger) and the objective of the best remaining node (BestBound). By default, RELOBJGAP=1E–4.

arguments.name: STRONGITER=
arguments.description: specifies the number of simplex iterations that PROC OPTGRAPH performs for each variable in the candidate list when it uses the strong branching variable selection strategy. If you specify the keyword AUTOMATIC or the value –1, PROC OPTGRAPH uses the default value, which it calculates automatically.

arguments.name: STRONGLEN=
arguments.description: specifies the number of candidates that PROC OPTGRAPH considers when it uses the strong branching variable selection strategy. If you specify the keyword AUTOMATIC or the value –1, PROC OPTGRAPH uses the default value, which it calculates automatically.

arguments.name: TARGET=
arguments.description: specifies a stopping criterion for minimization problems. The value of number can be any number; the default is the negative number that has the largest absolute value that can be represented in your operating environment.

arguments.name: VARSEL=
arguments.description: specifies the rule for selecting the branching variable. By default, VARSEL=AUTOMATIC.

arguments.name: AUTOMATIC
arguments.description: uses automatic branching variable selection

arguments.name: MAXINFEAS
arguments.description: chooses the variable with maximum infeasibility

arguments.name: MININFEAS
arguments.description: chooses the variable with minimum infeasibility

arguments.name: PESUDO
arguments.description: chooses a branching variable based on pseudocost

arguments.name: STRONG
arguments.description: uses strong branching variable selection strategy
